Award.AwardTitle: CBMS Conference: Introduction to the theory of valuations on convex sets
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund an NSF/CBMS conference at Kent State University in the summer of 2015 on the topic of valuations. Valuations are certain algebraic quantities introduced in order to better understand geometric problems. The main lecturer will be Semyon Alesker from Tel Aviv University. In his lectures, Alesker will give self-contained introduction to the subject, while also lecturing on the most recent developments on the structure of valuations. This will provide researchers from a variety of areas of mathematics with the opportunity to learn the techniques of the subject, and how they can be applied to a wide range of problems in analysis, geometry, and probability. While several classical texts have been written in this area, the extent to which Alesker's work has revolutionized the field makes it difficult for researchers to find a text which is self-contained, and at the same time describes the state of the art in the subject. The lectures (and subsequent monograph) of Semyon Alesker are going to fill this gap, benefitting many researchers and students. Interaction among participants at the conference from different parts of the mathematical sciences community is likely to bring fresh perspectives to an evolving field, stimulating the development of new avenues of research and uncovering new areas of application.

The theory of valuations (finitely-additive measures on convex compact sets) is a classical part of convex geometry with traditionally strong relations to integral geometry. Its initial development was motivated by Dehn's solution of the 3rd Hilbert problem. The systematic development of continuous valuations was initiated by Hadwiger in the 40's and 50's, and further developed by P. McMullen (amongst others) in the 1970s and 1980s. In the proposed lecture series, the classical theory of Hadwiger and McMullen will be discussed in detail, before moving onto to the more recent developments which have arisen since the work of Klain and Schneider in the mid-1990s. One of the highlights of the lecture series will be an essentially complete proof of Alesker's irreducibility theorem, which, amongst its many consequences, proved a conjecture of McMullen dating from 1980. Alesker's more recent theory of valuations on manifolds will also be described. Throughout the lecture series, special attention will be drawn to applications of the theory of valuations to convex and integral geometry (questions involving the theory of intrinsic volumes, characterization theorems of invariant measures, and kinematic formulas). The interest in the subject is based upon its importance in order to achieve progress in solving different problems related to convex geometry and geometric probability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CBMS conference Introduction to the theory of valuations was held at Kent State University from the 10th--14th August 2015, with principal lecturer Semyon Alesker (Tel-Aviv University), a highly distinguished geometer whose honors include the Prize of the European Mathematical Society, and the Erdos Prize.

The main goal of Alesker's talks was to familiarize the participants with the techniques around an area of geometry known as valuation theory, taking the participants from the most classical results, to recent technical breakthroughs.  Valuations  have played an important role in geometry ever since they were introduced by M. Dehn (1900) in his solution to Hilbert's third problem. 

Alesker delivered 10 exceptional lectures on the subject, as evidenced by comments sent by participants not necessarily too familiar with the theory.  For instance, Bochen Liu, a graduate student at Rochester working in harmonic analysis wrote,  "One thing I want to say is, this conference is really friendly to those who are not familiar with valuation theory. The main speaker's lectures were fundamental. And the schedules of lectures and technical talks are very reasonable so that people who are not experts, like me, followed most of them".  Maria Alfonseca (University of South Dakota), wrote that "The conference was very good. I thought that the pace of the main speaker was excellent to allow newcomers to the area to follow the arguments.  The logistics of the conference (food, lodging, transportation) were also seamless".   Omar Rivasplata (University of Alberta) wrote "Personally, I knew virtually nothing about valuations on convex sets before; the lectures were a great opportunity to learn about this fascinating area and fill in enough to appreciate the research in this direction. Besides, this conference was a nice opportunity for me to visit friends and colleagues. All in all, it was a fantastic experience! I very much look forward to future conferences that you may organize".

Outside of Alesker's talks, there were several more technical research talks from Joe Fu (University of Georgia, USA), Monika Ludwig (Vienna University of Technology, Austria), Rolf Schneider  (Albert-Ludwigs-Universität Freiburg, Germany), Franz Schuster (TU Wein, Austria), Gil Solanes (Universitat Autónoma de Barcelona, Spain), and Wolfgang Weil (Karlsruher Institute of Technology, Germany).  Although this resulted in quite a full program, there were also extended breaks for discussions.

Bringing together such a distinguished group of geometers lead to lively discussions and exciting new opportunities for collaboration.  Franz Schuster (TU Wien) wrote "I just wanted to give you guys some feedback about the wonderful and interesting conference `Introduction to the theory of valuations and convex sets' at Kent State University.  Not only my graduate students but also I really enjoyed the well balanced program of introductory and educational lectures and the more research oriented lectures on advanced topics. During the breaks I had the opportunity to discuss several topics with experts in the field as well as meet new and younger colleagues who are just starting to work in the area. Both these types of interactions I found very rewarding and I am even optimistic that I could start a couple of new collaborations with other scientists from integral geometry".
